See also: Erosion
Landscaping is an investment that can add value to your home. It can also provide you with satisfaction and enjoyment. You must maintain your landscaping for it to continue to grow and stay beautiful.
SOIL, WATER & FERTILIZER
These are the 3 keys to understanding how to maintain your homes landscaping.

• Check your pH twice a year.
• Adjust as necessary (check with a garden center to determine how to adjust your pH).
• Do not take pH lightly, it is very important to a healthy landscape.
• Maintaining the pH should be a major part of your maintenance program.
• If you have your maintenance work contracted out, ask that they give you a report on the status of your pH at least twice a year.
Watering new grass, plants, trees, and shrubs is very important...
The following are some general guidelines for new plantings:
Know your soil conditions...
•Small shrubs and plants usually require 2 gallons of water per shrub every other day for thirty (30) days.
•Small trees usually require about 4 gallons of water every other day for thirty (30) days.
•Large trees generally require between 6 - 12 gallons of water every other day for sixty (60) days.
• Water slowly to give the grass, plants, shrubs and trees the amount of water needed.
•Take into account rainfall and temperature when deciding when and how much to water, too much water is just as bad as not enough water.
•Try to water when temperatures are at the coolest times of the day (if possible).
•Use caution when watering at night, as fungus and mold can also form.
It is also recommend that you fertilize all grass, trees, shrubs, and plants a minimum of four times a year. However, best results usually are obtained by a professional landscape service familiar with the needs in your area.

Certain plants such as roses need to be fertilized more often. Identify each plant in your landscaping package and visit a local garden center for care sheets specific to their needs.
Balanced fertilization & Weed control...
Weeds can be present even in newly established yards and freshly sodded yards. Remember, the sod was likely cut from a field where who knows what was growing previously. It is recommended that you start a weed control program before you actually start to see weeds. If you are unsure what kind of weed you need to kill, take a sample to your local garden center to help identify it and pick a weed killer that will be effective. Be sure to follow all safety and user guidelines specific to the weed control / killer you purchase.

For best results, avoid hot dry days or rainy weather, which can both reduce the effectiveness of the herbicide. Quickest results are gained with applications when dormant sods are reactivated through the next few months. Even better results can be obtained if the lawn is given a feed the week before, for example by watering with a pellet type fertiliser. After a week application of the weed killer permits the broadleaved weeds to grow very fast, quickly withering from the weed control and then later dying.
